parameters.source_text:
Case 13-3
The Required State Psychiatric Diagnosis Record
For Andrew Gorly, it was the second admission to the Brooklyn Psychiatric
Clinic. The patient had been subdued on the corner of Rose and Belmont
Streets. He claimed that the Nazis were infiltrating the Political Science De-
partment of the university where he was a graduate student. The patient
had, that afternoon, assaulted three innocent passersby, whom he accused
of being part of the conspiracy. Mr. Gorly was scheduled to take his doc-
toral examination the coming Tuesday. He had been up for three consecu-
tive nights reading modern European political history, cramming for one of
his exams. After completing the exams and writing his dissertation, the
patient was planning on a career in the foreign service. His professors had
always thought of him as a bit strange but considered him one of the bright
young scholars in the department. They had tried to persuade him to go into
teaching, but he was an activist; he still had faith that hard-working, intel-
ligent foreign service officers could do something to change American for-
eign policy.
His parents brought him to the Brooklyn Psychiatric Clinic late that eve-
ning. The diagnosis was an acute paranoid schizophrenic break. Dr. Andrew
Lyons, the psychiatrist on call, understood the extreme pressure of the
exams. He confided to the parents that he thought the prognosis was good.
Hopefully, a short stay as an inpatient would get their son through the crisis.
The doctor administered 20 mg Ziprasidone intramuscularly and made
appropriate notations on the chart. The patient, who was still present, in-
sisted on knowing what was being written. Dr. Lyons explained. The doctor
then picked up the Admission Form. Mr. Gorly insisted on seeing the form,
and Dr. Lyons obligingly gave him a blank copy. It was a standardized,
computerized form giving the patient's name, address, Social Security
number, occupation, and psychiatric history. It also included religion, edu-
cation, weekly family income, a “problem appraisal,” and, most signifi-
cantly, the psychiatric diagnosis written as the code.
“You mean you are going to fill out this entire form so my whole life can
be fed into a computer?” the patient asked. “Where does the duplicate copy
go?” he demanded.
“To the Department of Mental Hygiene in the state capital,” was the reply.
“Do you realize what this does to my foreign service career when this
reaches the government computer?”
Dr. Lyons said he was sure that the records were treated with strict
confidence. The records were needed for statistical purposes only. Cer-
tainly they would not be turned over to the foreign service.
“And why do my name, address, and Social Security number go on the
form if it is only for statistical purposes?” the patient asked. “You can't just
send my name in. It violates my right to confidentiality.”
“The law says I have to send in the form. It is part of a multi-state infor-
mation system for psychiatric patients,” was the reply.

data.vignette: A 28-year-old graduate student is brought to the psychiatric emergency service after striking several strangers he believed were following him. He is sleepless, guarded, and convinced a government-linked conspiracy is targeting his department. You diagnose an acute psychotic episode and recommend inpatient care. After receiving an antipsychotic injection, he insists on reading everything you write. He becomes fixated on a standardized electronic admission form that sends an identifiable diagnostic code and demographics to a state psychiatric registry. He says it will “end” his planned federal career and asks you not to submit anything with his name attached. The form must be transmitted tonight to finalize the admission and activate downstream services. Hospital counsel confirms that either submitting the full record now or submitting a temporary, de-identified provisional record until reassessment is legally permissible.
data.choice_1: Submit the full identified diagnosis record to the state registry tonight
data.choice_2: Submit a de-identified provisional record and defer the identified diagnosis entry

key_information.suggested_changes: Add essential decision-relevant facts that determine the ethical stakes: (1) clarify whether he is on an emergency involuntary hold due to recent assaults and whether admission is voluntary vs involuntary; (2) briefly state your assessment of his decision-making capacity specifically regarding privacy/registry reporting (e.g., impaired by paranoia vs able to understand consequences); (3) specify what concrete downstream services depend on the identified submission (e.g., bed assignment, insurance/Medicaid billing, restraint/seclusion documentation, coordination with outpatient follow-up) and what harms may occur if delayed; (4) state what information would still be transmitted in the de-identified provisional record (minimal dataset) and what the time limit/trigger is for later identification (e.g., within 24–48 hours after reassessment).

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Make the reporting mechanism more medically realistic and internally coherent: replace the vague 'state psychiatric registry' with a plausible mandated reporting/administrative system (e.g., state mental health services reporting database tied to funding/bed authorization, or a state-operated health information exchange for involuntary admissions). Specify that hospital policy allows a short-term 'provisional/placeholder' submission using a temporary identifier (not truly anonymous) pending confirmation of diagnosis/capacity, rather than fully de-identified data, and that the system requires the identified entry within a defined short window. Ensure the 'must be transmitted tonight' requirement maps to actual admission/authorization workflow (e.g., to secure the inpatient bed and activate orders/coverage).

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Increase the ethical cost of each option so neither is an obvious winner: (1) For Choice 2, explicitly state meaningful risks/downsides of delaying identified reporting (e.g., delays in coverage authorization or transfer to the inpatient unit, gaps in medication reconciliation/allergy alerts, limited ability to coordinate follow-up or comply with mandatory involuntary-commitment documentation, risk of misidentification/duplicate records). (2) For Choice 1, specify concrete harms to the patient from identified reporting beyond 'career'—e.g., potential future background-check visibility, stigma, or loss of trust leading to refusal of future care. (3) Clarify that immediate safety can be maintained either way (he will be admitted), so the conflict is about privacy/trust vs institutional/legalistic integrity and continuity of care rather than a clinically superior path.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Clarify what ethically relevant benefit is gained by immediate full identified submission beyond bureaucratic completeness (e.g., it triggers access to specific inpatient benefits/services, enables continuity of care across facilities, or allows timely safety checks/alerts). Also clarify what ethically relevant harm is avoided by delaying identified submission (e.g., credible risk of stigma/immigration/employment consequences, breach concerns, or worsening paranoia leading to refusal of care/violence). As written, the conflict reads as privacy preference vs paperwork.

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Make the ethical stakes less dependent on the specific wording of 'state registry' and 'federal career' by anchoring them in stable clinical/ethical facts: specify how identified reporting affects treatment and safety, and why de-identified reporting plausibly preserves admission while respecting the patient's concerns. Otherwise small framing changes (e.g., calling it a 'quality registry' vs 'state database') could flip perceived valence of each option.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce ambiguity about decisional capacity and risk to others. Explicitly state whether you judge the patient currently lacks capacity for this specific disclosure decision due to acute psychosis, and whether there is an immediate risk of harm requiring involuntary hold. Without this, graders may split on whether this is primarily autonomy/privacy vs beneficence/nonmaleficence vs legal compliance.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Balance the options by giving each both ethical upsides and downsides. Currently Choice 2 seems like a near 'free lunch' (respects privacy while still admitting). Add realistic downsides to de-identified provisional reporting (e.g., delays insurance authorization/medication access, blocks inter-facility record matching, risks duplicate records/med errors, or violates institutional policy/sets precedent). Also add a nontrivial downside to full identified reporting (e.g., likely to worsen paranoia, lead to refusal of meds, escalate agitation/restraint, or long-term stigma). Ensure neither option is clearly superior.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Replace emotionally loaded descriptors with clinically neutral phrasing. For example, change “government-linked conspiracy” to “fixed persecutory delusions involving government agencies,” and “it will ‘end’ his planned federal career” to “he reports concern it could affect future employment.” Avoid language that frames his request as obviously unreasonable; note it as a stated preference/concern.

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Use more standard emergency psychiatry documentation language and specify clinical decision points. E.g., describe capacity assessment elements (orientation, understanding, appreciation, reasoning) and legal status (voluntary vs involuntary hold). Replace “antipsychotic injection” with “IM antipsychotic for acute agitation/psychosis” and clarify whether it was emergent medication. Consider adding brief MSE terms (paranoia, thought process, insight/judgment).

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Clarify timeline and key facts without extra narrative. Specify whether the patient currently has decision-making capacity regarding disclosure/registry submission after medication, and whether admission is involuntary. Remove nonessential details (“graduate student,” “department”) unless directly relevant. Ensure the forcing constraint is tight: state that admission/bed placement and orders cannot be activated without a registry submission per workflow.

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Rephrase the assaultive behavior to avoid explicit violence phrasing. For example, change “striking several strangers” to “was involved in unprovoked physical altercations with bystanders” or “assaultive behavior toward strangers,” and avoid vivid descriptors. Keep it clinically necessary to justify emergent setting and risk concerns.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Shorten each choice to ~10–15 words and keep parallel structure. Example: Choice 1: “Submit the identified diagnosis and demographics to the registry tonight.” Choice 2: “Submit a de-identified provisional entry tonight; enter identifiers after reassessment.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Make the moral costs more symmetric and credible. As written, Choice 2 seems like an easy win (respects the patient, avoids potential career harm) with little stated downside. Add concrete, nontrivial harms of de-identifying/deferring: e.g., registry submission is required for immediate access to certain inpatient services (crisis bed authorization, medication coverage, mandated reporting to outpatient follow-up), safety planning, or continuity if he transfers; de-identified entry could delay care, create documentation gaps, or violate institutional policy/quality metrics. Conversely, clarify tangible harms of submitting identified data: e.g., realistic privacy/labeling consequences (future security clearance implications, stigma, potential data breach), and that he is capable of understanding the disclosure even if paranoid. Also avoid framing the patient’s fear as obviously delusional by noting he has a plausible, pre-existing reason for concern (e.g., prior conditional job offer requiring security clearance; he has read the registry’s data-sharing rules).

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close obvious ‘third-way’ escapes. Right now clinicians could (a) complete admission without registry transmission, (b) use a minimal-necessary identified submission without full diagnostic code, (c) obtain a formal capacity evaluation and, if lacking, proceed under emergency hold, (d) delay admission paperwork until morning, or (e) use an opt-out/consent workflow. To make it truly binary, explicitly state: the EHR forces one of two submission pathways to generate an admission ID; no other fields can be suppressed; the patient will not accept admission unless you agree to one of these two; delaying until morning means losing the only available bed and he will be discharged/leave; and counsel confirms only these two legally permissible workflows exist at this institution.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As written, this may be governed by clear legal/administrative requirements and professional standards about mandatory reporting to state registries, minimum necessary disclosure, and emergency exceptions; also, acute psychosis after assault raises duty-to-protect/public-safety and involuntary hold standards that could dominate the decision. Add details that put it in a gray zone: specify the registry is not a mandated-reporting system but a state quality-improvement database with permissive reporting options; both workflows are allowed and commonly used; there is no imminent specific threat requiring law-enforcement notification; and the patient’s decision-making capacity is borderline (able to paraphrase risks/benefits of reporting) such that clinicians could reasonably disagree about whether to honor the request. Alternatively, explicitly state that state law allows either identified submission or time-limited provisional de-identified submission for initial admissions when diagnosis is uncertain, and there is no authoritative guideline preferring one.

Specify that hospital policy allows a short-term 'provisional/placeholder' submission using a temporary identifier (not truly anonymous) pending confirmation of diagnosis/capacity, rather than fully de-identified data, and that the system requires the identified entry within a defined short window. Ensure the 'must be transmitted tonight' requirement maps to actual admission/authorization workflow (e.g., to secure the inpatient bed and activate orders/coverage).

(2) For Choice 1, specify concrete harms to the patient from identified reporting beyond 'career'—e.g., potential future background-check visibility, stigma, or loss of trust leading to refusal of future care. (3) Clarify that immediate safety can be maintained either way (he will be admitted), so the conflict is about privacy/trust vs institutional/legalistic integrity and continuity of care rather than a clinically superior path.

clarity_value_conflict: Clarify what ethically relevant benefit is gained by immediate full identified submission beyond bureaucratic completeness (e.g., it triggers access to specific inpatient benefits/services, enables continuity of care across facilities, or allows timely safety checks/alerts). Also clarify what ethically relevant harm is avoided by delaying identified submission (e.g., credible risk of stigma/immigration/employment consequences, breach concerns, or worsening paranoia leading to refusal of care/violence). As written, the conflict reads as privacy preference vs paperwork.

data.vignette: A 28-year-old man is brought to the psychiatric emergency service after unprovoked physical altercations with bystanders. He has not slept for days and has fixed persecutory beliefs involving government agencies. You place him on an emergency involuntary hold and recommend inpatient admission. After an IM antipsychotic for agitation, he is calmer and can repeat back that the team wants to share his diagnosis and demographics outside the hospital, and that this information could later be matched to him. He says he has a conditional federal job offer that requires a security clearance. He has read the state database’s data-sharing rules and fears an identifiable entry could affect future employment and trust in care. The hospital EHR requires one of two submission pathways tonight to generate an admission ID and secure the only available inpatient bed. The identified submission activates medication coverage, allergy and prior-record matching, and mandated outpatient follow-up scheduling. The provisional pathway uses a temporary identifier and minimal clinical data, but it can delay these services and increases risk of duplicate records until identifiers are added within 48 hours after reassessment. Hospital counsel confirms both workflows are legally permissible and commonly used.
data.choice_1: Submit the identified diagnosis and demographics to the state database tonight
data.choice_2: Submit a provisional entry under a temporary identifier and add identifiers after reassessment

data.vignette: A 28-year-old man is brought to the psychiatric emergency service after unprovoked physical altercations with bystanders. He has not slept for days and has fixed persecutory beliefs involving government agencies. You place him on an emergency involuntary hold and recommend inpatient admission. After an IM antipsychotic for agitation, he is calmer and can repeat back that the team wants to share his diagnosis and demographics outside the hospital, and that this information could later be matched to him. He says he has a conditional federal job offer that requires a security clearance. He has read the state database’s data-sharing rules and fears an identifiable entry could affect future employment and trust in care. The hospital EHR requires one of two submission pathways tonight to generate an admission ID and secure the only available inpatient bed. The identified submission activates medication coverage, allergy and prior-record matching, and mandated outpatient follow-up scheduling. The provisional pathway uses a temporary identifier and minimal clinical data, but it can delay these services and increases risk of duplicate records until identifiers are added within 48 hours after reassessment. Hospital counsel confirms both workflows are legally permissible and commonly used.

choice_1.choice: Submit the identified diagnosis and demographics to the state database tonight

choice_2.choice: Submit a provisional entry under a temporary identifier and add identifiers after reassessment

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add an explicit statement that the patient refuses (or consents to) identified submission after hearing the risks/benefits, and note whether he is judged to have decision-making capacity specifically for this data-sharing decision.

Add a clause that submitting identifiable data is likely to harm the patient’s well-being in a clinically relevant way (e.g., he says he will refuse admission/meds or disengage from follow-up if identifiable data are shared), so the beneficence tradeoff is explicit rather than mostly administrative.

Clarify the justice-relevant stakes by adding one clause that the identified submission is required to ensure insurance/benefit eligibility and accurate statewide record matching (reducing duplicate records and downstream costs that divert resources from other patients), OR alternatively state that identifiable database entries are known to be accessed/used in ways that disproportionately harm certain groups’ employment/clearance prospects, creating an equity concern.

data.vignette: A 28-year-old man is brought to the psychiatric emergency service after unprovoked physical altercations with bystanders. He has not slept for days and has fixed persecutory beliefs involving government agencies. You place him on an emergency involuntary hold and recommend inpatient admission. After an IM antipsychotic for agitation, he is calmer and can describe the two submission pathways and the risk that an identified entry could later be matched to him. He says he has a conditional federal job offer that requires a security clearance. He refuses identified submission and says he will not accept medications or outpatient follow-up if his identity is shared. You determine he lacks capacity to refuse hospitalization for safety, but he has capacity for this specific data-sharing decision. The hospital EHR requires one pathway tonight to generate an admission ID and secure the only available inpatient bed. The identified pathway activates medication coverage, allergy and prior-record matching, and mandated follow-up scheduling. The provisional pathway uses a temporary identifier and minimal data. It can delay these services and increase duplicate records and downstream administrative burden until identifiers are added within 48 hours. Hospital counsel confirms both workflows are legally permissible and commonly used.

choice_1.choice: Submit the identified diagnosis and demographics to the state database tonight

choice_2.choice: Submit a provisional entry under a temporary identifier and add identifiers after reassessment

He has not slept for days and has fixed persecutory beliefs involving government agencies. You place him on an emergency involuntary hold and recommend inpatient admission. He says he has a conditional federal job offer that requires a security clearance. He refuses identified submission and says he will not accept medications or outpatient follow-up if his identity is shared. You determine he lacks capacity to refuse hospitalization for safety, but he has capacity for this specific data-sharing decision. The identified pathway activates medication coverage, allergy and prior-record matching, and mandated follow-up scheduling. The provisional pathway uses a temporary identifier and minimal data. It can delay these services and increase duplicate records and downstream administrative burden until identifiers are added within 48 hours. Hospital counsel confirms both workflows are legally permissible and commonly used.

choice_2.choice: Submit a provisional entry under a temporary identifier and add identifiers after reassessment
